markdown_preview:
# [BUG] NullReferenceException in OrderProcessor.ProcessOrder when Items is null

**Source**: Migrated from JIRA [ECOM-1234](https://company.atlassian.net/browse/ECOM-1234)

## Description

The ProcessOrder method accesses order.Items.Sum() without first checking if Items is null...

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an Order object with null Items property
2. Call ProcessOrder(order) method
3. Observe NullReferenceException

## Expected Behavior

The method should validate the order object and handle null Items collection gracefully...

## Actual Behavior

The code throws NullReferenceException when attempting to access order.Items without null checking.

```csharp
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
   at OrderProcessor.ProcessOrder(Order order) in OrderProcessor.cs:line 45
   at OrderService.HandleNewOrder(Order order) in OrderService.cs:line 23
```

## Environment

- **OS**: Windows 11
- **.NET Version**: .NET 6.0
- **Component**: OrderProcessing
- **Affected Version**: v2.4.0

## Stack Trace / Error Output

```csharp
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
   at OrderProcessor.ProcessOrder(Order order) in OrderProcessor.cs:line 45
   at OrderService.HandleNewOrder(Order order) in OrderService.cs:line 23
```

## Severity

**High** - Feature unavailable or severely degraded

## Workaround

Workaround: Manually check if order.Items is null before processing. We've added this check in the API layer for now.

## Related Issues

- **Relates**: ECOM-1100 - Legacy API creates orders without initializing collections

## Screenshots / Attachments

- [exception-screenshot.png](https://company.atlassian.net/secure/attachment/10050/exception-screenshot.png) (45678 bytes)

## Root Cause Analysis

The ProcessOrder method accesses order.Items.Sum() without first checking if Items is null. This occurs when orders are created through the legacy API which doesn't initialize the Items collection.
